div.head: I. Pietro d’Abano’s Expositio problematum Aristotelis
1.1 General
div.p: The pseudo-Aristotelian Problems is an extensive collection of questions and proposed answers concerning a wide range of subjects, including biology, mathematics, and physics, divided topically into thirty-eight sections. The nineteenth of these sections preserves the first substantial account of ancient Greek music making and theorizing to have been rediscovered in the medieval period. This material held great promise for medieval thinkers seeking to learn more about the foreign world of ancient Greek music, whose legendary emotional power had been lamentedly lost, and the text’s attribution to Aristotle imbued it with special authority. Yet the Problems was also a challenging text to decipher. Not only was the subject manner often unfamiliar, the manuscript tradition of the Greek text is also corrupt in places. Furthermore, the first complete Latin translation, made by Bartholomew of Messina (fl. 1258–66), observed the common medieval practice of verbatim, indeed servilely literal, word-for-word translation. For all these reasons, potential readers of the Problems were in sore need of orientation and explanation.

Into the breach strode Pietro d’Abano (c. 1257–1316), who was a professor of medicine with wide-ranging interests and expertise. Pietro composed his Expositio, the first commentary on the entirety of the Problems in the first decade of the fourteenth century, and there are more than twenty extant manuscripts of it, as well as multiple early print editions. His commentary also attracted the attention of his contemporaries, most notably Jean de Jandun (c. 1285–1328), a philosopher and theologian of considerable importance based at the University of Paris, who produced a revision of the entire Expositio. Moreover, Pietro’s commentary on the problems of section XIX, in particular, was the first widely circulated medieval attempt to interpret and assimilate rediscovered knowledge about music in the ancient world, and his explanations consequently became a touchstone for later generations of music scholars who referred to the Problems, including Franchino Gaffurio, Girolamo Mei, and Francisco de Salinas. Most recently, Claude Palisca has called attention to Pietro’s anticipation of Renaissance modes of scholarship (1985), and David E. Cohen has demonstrated that Pietro’s idiosyncratic interpretations of some of the problems concerning music played an important role in the development of the music-theoretical concept of harmony (2012). Yet despite the inherent interest of Pietro’s commentary as a site of cross-cultural engagement and its historical significance to later music theorizing, his commentary on section XIX, on music, has been inaccesible to scholars, for until recently it had not been published in any form since the sixteenth century’s sadly unreliable print editions. Even that recent publication (Meyer 2022), however, does not provide a proper critical edition of the text, as it is based on a sixteenth-century print edition, only considers half the extant manuscripts, and fails to distinguish between Pietro's first version of his commentary and his later revision (see section 2.1). The present critical edition rectifies that situation, establishing a base text informed by a stemmatic hypothesis of the complete manuscript tradition. Furthermore, this edition is openly accessible, and it presents a semantically encoded version of the text, allowing readers to select the types of variants they wish to consider. As a result, it provides a better informed version of Pietro's commentary and makes it more widely available than ever before.

div.head: 1.2 Structure
div.p: Each of the pseudo-Aristotelian problems follows a set structure. First, a question is posed, such as at the start the first problem: Why do those who are suffering and those who are rejoicing have pipes played for them? (Propter quid dolentes et gaudentes fistulantur?) Then one or more possible reasons are proposed, often accompanied by additional explanation. For instance, the first problem continues: Is it so that the former mourn less, but the latter rejoice more? (Aut vt hii quidem minus tristentur, alii autem vt magis gaudeant?) In his commentary Pietro follows a similar pattern. He first paraphrases the opening question, and then addresses the remainder of the problem, dividing it into between one and seven parts, depending on its length. He signals the beginning of each successive division of the text with its first word or two, followed by a partial or complete paraphrase. (These paraphrases are enclosed by targeted "gloss" elements in the xml format, and they are italicized in the rendered pdf.) Given the unidiomatic Latin of Bartholomew of Messina’s translation and the common occurrence of obscure vocabulary, Pietro’s paraphrases provide an important means of ingress to the text on their own. He often supplements these paraphrases with additional explanatory material, both his own and by authors from antiquity. In the latter case, he often provides cross-references to other pertinent passages within the Problems (from both section XIX and other sections), and he also inserts abbreviated quotations, most often from the Aristotelian and medical corpora.

div.head: 2.1 Introduction
div.p: Establishing the best text of Pietro d’Abano’s commentary is no simple task, for it survives in several different forms. By analyzing variants in the introduction with which Pietro starts his commentary on the Problems, Gijs Coucke has demonstrated that Pietro produced a revised version of his commentary after the initial version was complete (2008, vol. 2, xlii–xliv). About a quarter of the extant manuscripts derive from the initial version, another quarter from the revision, and the remaining half of the manuscripts descend from the revision made by Jean de Jandun (concerning which see Swaenepoel 2009). While these latter manuscripts do not aid in the reconstruction of the text(s) Pietro himself wrote, they provide important testimony as to the work’s reception in the Parisian university scene, and consequently I have recorded variants from five selected manuscripts in the critical apparatus. Coucke notes that “all manuscripts appear to have the identical explicit, which refers to 1310 as the year in which Peter finished his Expositio” (2008, vol. 2, xliv)—that presumably being the date when the initial version was completed.

Further complicating matters, some of the manuscripts change affiliations partway through the lengthy work. As Joan Cadden has observed, manuscript Pz contains the first half of Pietro’s version and the second half of Jean’s, and manuscript Ea has the converse arrangement (2013, 228). Additionally, in his edition of section IV of the Expositio, Coucke identifies manuscript Vb as deriving from Pietro’s revised version, whereas by section XIX it hews more closely to the initial version. (Furthermore, manuscript Pq contains Jean’s version in sections IV and XIX, but by section XXVII it appears to have changed to Pietro’s version [Coucke 2008, vol. 2, xxvi].) As a result, I have preserved Coucke’s manuscript sigils, but not his labeling of families and conjectured sub-types. For instance, Coucke labels Pietro’s first and second versions Pa and Pb, respectively whereas I call them α and κ. (This change is made in part to avoid the confusing use of letters in Coucke’s Conspectus siglorum, where the manuscripts elsewhere labeled as Pb are listed under heading A, and those as Pa under heading B.)

In classifying the manuscripts I used Coucke’s findings on section IV as a point of departure. I collated all the manuscripts’ versions of section XIX’s tenth problem to test the validity of Coucke’s findings to section XIX. Then I collated all the manuscripts representing solely either Pietro’s first or his second version (with the exception of Mb, to be discussed below), along with manuscripts Ea and Pz (since their classification differs between sections IV and XIX), and four representative manuscripts from the Jean de Jandun redaction.

div.head: 2.3 Pietro d’Abano’s First Version
div.p: The first version of Pietro’s commentary on section XIX of the Problems, which I label α, is found in five manuscripts: Nu, Py, Va, Vb, and Ea. Manuscripts Nu and Py usually carry the best version of this text. Unfortunately, Nu’s codex has lost a number of pages, resulting in total loss of the text from a point partway into problem 9 through problem 15, and again from the end of problem 38 through the end of the section.

Manuscripts Va and Vb are associated by shared error. The most salient of these occurs in problem 20, where they repeatedly mistake discussion of the Greek language (oratio greca) for “grammatical speech” (oratio gramatica). The scribe of manuscript Va evidently prioritized speed over neatness of script and also had very idiosyncratic orthography, regularly doubling single consonants or omitting one where they are normally doubled. Given the ubiquity of these variants, I have omitted them from the critical apparatus unless they are shared by other manuscripts. In his edition of section IV, Coucke finds that Vb contains the second version of Pietro’s commentary, but by section XIX there is little evidence of Vb sharing readings characteristic of that second version. In addition, the sub-family represented by Va and Vb is particularly important for the commentary’s reception history since the incunable editions of the text align most closely with them.

The situation is more complicated with manuscript Ea. Coucke assigns manuscript Ea to the Jean de Jandun redaction, and in section XIX the manuscript adopts many (though not all) of the omissions that characterize that redaction, and it sometimes shares readings with Pz. Nonetheless, in non-omitted passages Ea’s text more closely resembles the manuscripts transmitting Pietro’s first version. As a result, I primarily affiliate it with that family of texts, with the proviso that the scribe of Ea evidently consulted a Pz-related manuscript from the Jandun redaction as well.

div.head: 2.4 Pietro d’Abano’s Second Version
div.p: The second version of Pietro’s commentary, which I label κ, is also found in five manuscripts: Px, Vm, Vz, Ma, and Mb. With respect to the fourth section, Coucke hypothesized that manuscripts Px and Vb (which in section IV transmits Pietro’s second version) most closely follow the original form of the second version, that a further revised form of the second version was the model for manuscripts Ma, Mb, and Pz, and that manuscript Vm shares common error with these latter three (Coucke 2008, vol. 2, xxxix). Only some of Coucke’s observations hold true in section XIX, however. I agree that a revised version, which I call λ, was the model for many of these manuscripts. As mentioned above, however, manuscript Vb has switched its affiliation and now follows Pietro’s first version, and Pz likewise has shifted to Jean of Jandun’s redaction. Additionally, Coucke does not consider Vz, since it does not contain section IV.

The resulting picture is that Px follows the original form of the second version, and that Ma, Mb, Vm, and Vz derive from λ, a revised version thereof. Coucke’s hypothesis of a further revised source for Ma, Mb, and Pz (but not Vm) is not supported in section XIX, since there is good reason to believe that Mb is copied either directly from Ma or from another copy of Ma. For instance, in problem 2 the scribe of Ma erroneously wrote unaa instead of una, and Mb’s scribe wrote unaa before deleting the superfluous a. Still stronger evidence of copying is found in problem 3’s table of Greek note names, where Mb’s scribe was consulting a manuscript that breaks the word prollabamenos (recte: proslambanomenos) into prolla and bamenos, as Ma does. We can tell this because Mb’s scribe evidently thought the line break divided two distinct words: in Mb, following prolla the rest of the line (about six characters’ worth) is left blank, before the table of note names begins at the top of the next column with bamenos. Furthermore, in problem 6 Mb’s scribe follows the word magnatis with the superfluous phrase vel huius est inequale non eundem seruans tenorem ahead of where it should occur in the text, and then repeats it in the correct place, following excellentis. In this case of homeoteleuton the -tis endings of magnatis and excellentis are nearly aligned in two successive lines of Ma (f. 97v), so it is very likely that Mb’s scribe’s eyes skipped from the end of magnatis down a line to excellentis, and then erroneously copied the words that followed. In sum, because my collation of Mb across the first ten problems revealed no meaningful discrepancies with Ma, but rather signs of direct copying, I conclude that it is not useful for establishing the best text of Pietro’s second version.

Of the remaining manuscripts in sub-family λ, Vm often preserves better readings than Ma and Vz. Zanetti dates Vz to about the fourteenth century (1741, 121), but it may have been copied later, as it is written on paper and is the only extant manuscript to be copied in a single column. I have examined its watermark, which is a bellflower with a five-petalled bell, two leaves that curl up, and a stem that curves sharply; it closely resembles watermark DE4620-PO-127158, which has been dated to 1447, in Rome, though its bell is straighter. Nonetheless, the manuscript's unique readings are not obviously inferior to those of Ma, so I have included its variants in the critical apparatus throughout.

div.head: 2.5 Jean de Jandun’s Redaction
div.p:
The redaction undertaken by Jean de Jandun necessarily cannot help reconstruct the best text of Pietro’s commentary, but it is still of some interest. This is in part because Jandun is one of the most important thinkers in the Latin Averroist tradition (South 2002, 372), and consequently his understanding of the Problems and Pietro’s commentary merits attention. Furthermore, due to the significant circulation of Jean’s redaction in the environs of the University of Paris it is valuable for understanding the Problems’ reception.
As a result, the xml version of this edition includes readings from five selected manuscripts of Jean’s redaction. In the interest of brevity, this pdf version usually presents only the best reading from that recension, unless other variants are of particular interest.

Three broad feature of Jean’s redaction identified by Coucke in section IV also occur in section XIX. First, the redaction is most saliently characterized by omissions that either cover well defined text-units (paragraphs, or entire (subordinate) clauses), or entail the removal of repetitive or superfluous speech (2008, vol. 2: xxvii). Second, as a whole the manuscripts of Jean’s redaction largely agree with those of Pietro’s first version, but on occasion they follow his second version instead, as Coucke found (xxx–xxxi). Third, as in section IV manuscript Vo appears to be most valuable for establishing the text of the redaction (xxxiii). It has almost no unique errors of any importance, but a brief passage in problem 9 (vtrobique existente. Et hoc quia in cantu), which it alone omits, indicates that it cannot be the direct (or at least the sole) model for the rest of the redaction’s manuscripts.

Beyond these broad characteristics, however, further clarity is elusive. Whereas Coucke found that manuscripts Pp and Vc are “contaminated,” since in section IV they complete the omissions which are otherwise characteristic of Jean’s redaction (xxxi–xxxii), in section XIX Pp never does so and Vc only sometimes does. Coucke then goes on to note of section IV (and he observes that Delaurenti’s [then]-in-progress edition of section VII confirms the same), that: The other representatives of J [Jean’s redaction], however, are hardly differentiated, and among them the relations are volatile and changing. Yet, the samples allow for a division of the manuscripts along two main branches: (1) one of them is built around Vo, Ca and Ea; (2) another unites the distinct pair Pq Pu (xxxii). Broad outlines of these relations among manuscripts are still present in section XIX: in the first branch, Ca and Vo are still closely related, but Ea now aligns better with Pietro’s first version. In the second branch, moreover, frequent agreements of Pq with Gu and Pu with Pp also emerge. The remaining manuscripts, Vc, Pa, and Sc, do not clearly align with either branch.

Given that Jean’s redaction cannot help to establish Pietro’s text, I have not collated all its manuscripts. In the interest of brevity, this pdf version usually presents only the best reading from that recension, unless other variants are of particular interest. I follow Coucke (xxxiv) in selecting manuscript Vo, due to its paucity of errors.

The xml version of this edition, by contrast, includes readings from four other selected manuscripts of Jean’s redaction. Again following Coucke, it includes Gu, because of that source's careful preparation and occasional unique variants. The xml version also collates manuscript Pz, on account of its interest as it switches from Pietro’s second version to Jean’s redaction. Because Coucke identified manuscripts Pu and Pq as constituting a differentiated branch in section IV, I selected manuscript Pu for inclusion, since by section XIX Pq closely matches Gu. And finally I included manuscript Pp to help establish the second branch’s readings. (Other manuscripts from Jean’s redaction are also occasionally cited when they support variants that would otherwise appear unique.)

div.head: III. Pietro d’Abano’s Practices of Quotation
div.p: In section XIX of his commentary Pietro employs quotations in the same two ways observed by Coucke in section IV: more literal quotations, which come immediately after the source’s reference (usually cited by the work’s author, title, and book number, when applicable), and loose paraphrases, which precede the reference (2008 vol. 2, lxi). To this general pattern we may add a more specific observation: in section XIX Pietro’s more literal quotations draw exclusively on Boethius and Isidore, and he uses them to lay out background information about the discipline of music’s terminology and its received history. He does this most prominently in problem 1, but also later, too, for example in problems 3, 7, and 16. Pietro uses paraphrases, by contrast, largely to support or exemplify his interpretive claims, and they come from a significantly wider range of sources, as will now be addressed.

The sources with which Pietro engages in section XIX fall into three main categories: the Aristotelian corpus, medical texts, and late-Antique writings on music. Pietro cites sources from the first category most frequently. Cross-references abound to passages within the Problems, from both section XIX and other sections, and Pietro also cites other Aristotelian works that were well known in his day, especially book VIII of the Politics. (Other Aristotelian works with which Pietro engages in medical-focused sections of the Problems, such as the De generatio animalium and De historia animalium [Coucke 2008, vol. 2, lxii], make no appearance here.)

Given section XIX’s dedication to the subject of music, the extent to which Pietro incorporates medical sources, the second category, undoubtedly speaks to his training as a physician. Three of these treatises are by Galen, whom Claude Palisca misidentified as an otherwise unknown author Balienus in a chapter on Pietro (1985, 55). The other medical sources range from the better known, such Avicenna’s Canon medicinae, to the obscure, for instance the Aphorismi of Yuḥannā ibn Māsawaiyh, which Pietro attributes to John of Damascus.

The number of texts in the third category, writings on music, is very small. While Pietro makes reference to Macrobius and Ptolemy, he demonstrates first-hand knowledge of only Boethius’s De institutione harmonica and the section (III.15–23) of Isidore’s Etymologies which concerns music. He also has at least passing familiarity with some aspects of medieval music theory, as he makes reference to the Guidonian tradition (traditio Guidonis) in problem 1 and on occasion employs solmization syllables, but he displays no further awareness of music-theoretical writing from after late Antiquity. (He is, however, certainly aware of his day’s musical culture, as he discusses antiphonal singing and medieval instruments, which are unmentioned in Boethius or Isidore.)

div.head: 4.1 Latin Translation by Bartholomew of Messina
div.p: The textual tradition of Bartholomew of Messina’s Latin translation of the pseudo-Aristotelian text is largely independent of Pietro’s commentary, as only six of the twenty extant medieval manuscripts of Pietro’s commentary include the entirety of Bartholomew’s translation. Furthermore, sixty manuscripts contain part or the entirety of Bartholomew’s text, compared to only around thirty for the commentary (Coucke 2008 vol. 1, xxxvi; vol. 2, xxiii). As a result, a critically established text of the Latin translation of section XIX is beyond the scope of this edition, though I am presently preparing one for publication elsewhere. For readers’ convenience, though, I have reconstructed the version of Bartholomew’s translation which Pietro likely consulted and have included it as a variant. The reconstruction is based on my draft critical edition, altered to reflect readings found in Pietro's commentary.

div.head: 4.2 The Expositio problematum by Pietro d’Abano
div.p: To constitute the text and the critical apparatus I have accounted for all the manuscripts containing Pietro’s first and second versions of the commentary (except for manuscript Mb, since it is a copy of Ma). The xml version of the edition includes all those readings, while this pdf version trims variants that are only found in one manuscript or have been deemed immaterial to the text's reconstruction. In this pdf version of the edition I have also included best readings from Jean of Jandun’s recension, usually based on manuscript Vo. Furthermore, readings from the two incunable editions are mentioned when they agree on a unique reading of interest or with variants found in other manuscripts.

In the edition’s text I aim to reconstruct Pietro’s second version of the commentary, and consequently readings shared by manuscript Px and family λ are preferred. Where their readings diverge, if either Px or λ agree with multiple manuscripts from Pietro’s first version, I prefer that shared text. Where the surviving manuscripts of Pietro’s second version are corrupt, manuscript Py (and Nu, when not lacunate) is generally preferred.

With respect to orthography, I have largely preserved medieval spellings, rather than changing them to classical Latin standards. (The most prominent exceptions are that words ending with -cio, -cia, and the like have been changed to –tia, etc., and the –ij and –ijs endings to –ii and –iis.) The xml version of this edition records most spelling variances in the apparatus, but they have been silently normalized in this pdf version unless they are of particular interest. All contractions have been silently expanded, including the ampersand and \Tironian et, and tall s has been changed to round s. I have ignored all changes of hand and/or ink for the marginal numbering of the problems.

Punctuation varies widely among the manuscripts. I initially adopted manuscript Px’s punctuation, which is relatively sparse. Thereafter I added further punctuation in keeping with modern practice, especially where it was lacking at points of significant syntactic divisions. I followed a similar practice with paragraph divisions, basing them on those found in Px, and adding others at moments clearly signaled by the text (such as new thoughts introduced by nosce quod, notandum, and the like).

Relatedly, it should be noted that in section XIX manuscript Va and the incunable editions mark the beginnings of new paragraphs with deinde. In Coucke's edition of section IV, however, he shows while that the manuscripts of Pietro’s second version (excepting Vb, which Coucke assigns to the second version) use deinde in that way, the remaining manuscripts do not. The change of practice in Va is easily explained: a new copyist takes over at f. 47r, at which point that use of deinde to mark new paragraphs begins. In the manuscripts from Pietro’s second version, by contrast, that use of deinde gradually fades away, and seems largely to disappear after problem 15 of section 11.

ysidorum in ethymologiis ethicis
Isidore of Seville, Etym. III.15.1 est peritia modulationis, sono cantuque consistens.

Dicitur etiam quod sit scientia numeri ad sonos proportionati proportionatos . Arist. An. post. 90a, 14–23
Que secundum ysidorum dicitur a muso
quasi a querendo quasi acquirendo id est acquirendo , quia per eam
vis ius carminum querebatur acquiritur . Vnde a poetis iouis et memorie filias
mutas musas esse confictum est, nam si
memoria soni soni memoria non teneantur, pereunt teneatur, pereunt teneatur, perit , cum non possint possunt possit scribi. Isidore of Seville, Etym., III.15.1–2
A nonnullis vero Aut a moys quod est aqua, quia
olim primitus olim amicus olim tali primitus
inuenta fuit fuit inuenta in illa, et in ydriis siue instrumentis aquaticis similiter exercita.
Refert autem moyses hanc inuenisse tubal de stirpe cayn ante diluuium. Isidore of Seville, Etym. III.16.1
Sed greci, vt apparet per macrobium et boecium, dicunt eam inuenisse pitagoram pictagori pitagorici
samium
sonitu malleorum, cum casu in publicum exiret ad fabros, et cordarum demum deinde impulsione. Boethius, De inst. mus. I.10 (Friedlein p. 196–7) Macrobius, Comm. in somn. Scip. II.1 (Eyssenhardt p. 572–575)

Diuiditur autem musica iuxta eosdem in mundanam, humanam, et organicam vel instrumentalem. Mundana vero quidem attenditur in sono armonico, quem causant orbes celestes, secundum pictagoram pithagoricos cum aliis musicis, differenter
commotos commoti . Sonum enim armonicum causant, sed eum non percipimus percipimus vt , dicunt, propter quod in auribus nostris a principio natiuitatis est complantatus propter hoc quod a principio nobis in auribus nostris natum est et complantatur , vt in eris eis apparet malleatoribus strepitum suum vix percipientibus consuetudine
quos quod aristotelem impugnat celi et mundi 2°. impugnat 2° celi et mundi.
Arist. De caelo, II.9, 290bl. 25

Musica vero humana dicitur que circa concordantiam elementorum elementa diuersorum ad inuicem in vno composito
vel compositionem corporis versatur, per eam ea enim natura spiritualis coniungitur corpori et rationalis rationalis
concorditer cum irrationali coniungitur
. Quod videtur a platonicis habitum ponentibus animam quandam armonicam fore consistentiam esse consistentiam . Vnde
datum in afforismis dictum est in afforismis damascenus in afforismis
colligatio anime et corporis corporis et anime secundum ordinis naturalis consonantiam facta est, vt substat subsistat , Yuḥannā ibn Māsawaiyh, Aph., (Vat. Lat. 2460, f. 39v, ll. 7–8) quare huius huiusmodi
musice musice naturali numeratione naturali
videntur videntur hec scientie supponi.

Instrumentalis vero dicitur que quibusdam exercetur armonicis instrumentis, que predicamentis videtur predicamentis videntur
fore esse considerationis
existens duplex
: nam quedam exercetur instrumento naturali, vt hominis voce, cum reliquis organis locutionis locutiuis , aut an artificiali. Et id multipliciter: aut tactu vt viellis, vel pulsu ceu seu sicut cimbalis, vel
flatu flatio
vt sicut in tubis, aut quasi omni modo omnino
sicut vt fistulis.

Que Qui iuxta ysidorum
diuiditur dicitur in armonicam metricam et rithimicam. Quarum
armonica graue in sonis et acutum et acutum in sonis discernit. Metrica est etiam que ratione probabili cognoscit mensuram diuersorum pedum vt heroycum, iambicum et heliacum. Rithimica vero vero est est que verborum incursionem inquirit iungit , vt aut an
suauiter vel an non suauiter sonus cohereat. Isidore of Seville, Etym. III.18.1–2

Que siquidem tria tripliciter ad genus videntur videtur concurrere cantilene, armonica tamen, vt tactum tactum est , consonantiam consonantia grauis et acuti attendit, rithimica rithimica vero
consonantiam consonantia terminationum, metrica vero temporum vt apparet in traditione introductione musice guidonis. Et circa hastres partes musice, et maxime duas priores, dubitat dubitabit
aristoteles vtilitas vero
musice est, Arist. Pol. VIII.5, 1339a, l. 11 quia delectat animos animas
excitat exercitat
, et affectus mouet, et furiam placat, siluestrem siluestre mansuescere facit
, vt apparet clangore, namque tubarum et similium fortiores redduntur bellatores. Similiter lassatos et
exercitio
laborioso laborioso et detentos reddit faciles facilius tollerare. Vnde politicorum 8°: musica habet delectationem naturalem propter quod omnibus etatibus et omnibus moribus vsus ipsius est amicus. Arist. Pol. VIII, 1340a, ll. 3–5

Recitat etiam
boecius boecium
pictagoram pictagoricas iuuenem furentem in combustionem combustione domus riualis in qua sortum scortum continebatur melodiis musicis musicum eius animum sedasse. Boeth. De inst. mus. I.1 (Friedlein p. 185, l. 3) Cuius vtilitatem subtilitatem tangit politicorum 8°,
ponitur ponuntur ponit enim vnum
ibi quatuor que debet adiscere puer: que sunt littere lingue
luctatiua luctatio musica et protractiua, Arist. Pol. VIII, 1337b, l. 23
ceu seu
scribere scriptura et pingere.

Querit igitur ergo
aristoteles more consueto solito
problema, dicens
: Quare dolentes et contristantes et contristantes et contristantes et tristantes et delectantes gaudentesque fistulas et vniversaliter vniuersaliter omnia instrumenta delectationem et gaudium gaudium et letitiam inducentia expedit audire? Vnde alexander
in problematibus et maxime quantum ad primam partem: Propter quid coram patientibus fistule et tympana. Ps.-Alex. Aph., Prob. I.78 (Vat. reg. lat. 747, f. 75v)

Nosce quod
omnes passiones licet omnes passiones
sint coniuncte sicut continetur , 1° de anima Arist. De an. I.1, 403a, l. 25(Cf. 403a l. 16) ; quedam tamen se plus plus se
tenet tenent ex parte corporis, vt dolere et delectari, alie vero ex parte anime vt gaudere et tristari; ita vt per vnum expressum aliud aristoteles audiat recitatum
.

Deinde.
AUT. AUT QUIA. Soluit dicens causam esse vt qui tristantur ac etiam et dolent minus contristentur tristentur et doleant propter propter melodiam vel iocunditatem inductam ex sonitu instrumenti. In oppositis oppositis vero causa extat extet existit vt magis gaudeant et delectentur iocundentur , si enim aliqui sunt iocundi addita causa iocunditatis, vt fistulationis
armonice armonia
amplius delectabuntur. delectabuntur amplius.

Nosce quod id illud potest contingere quia idem potest esse causa diuersorum aut ratione ratione diuersorum aut ratione dispositionis susceptiui; vel quia diuersa egeant agat
eadem eodem
vel
ratione eius quod per se aut an et per accidens extat, vt nauta sui presentiam causa causa est salutis nauis, eius vero absentia submersionis 2° physicorum. Arist. Phys. II.3, 195a, l. 13

div.head: Secundum problema
div.p:
PROPTER QUID LONGIUS IDEM EADEM UOCE AUDITUR CUM ALIIS CANTANS ET CLAMANS QUAM SOLUS? AUT QUIA COADUNATE ALIQUID FACERE, AUT REPRIMERE AUT IMPELLERE, NON TANTA PROPE SUNT QUANTUS NUMERUS. SED SICUT LINEA BIPEDALIS NON DUPLUM SED QUADRUPLUM ALIQUID SCRIBIT, ITA COMPOSITA PLUS POSSUNT, AUT SECUNDUM NUMERUM AUT QUANDO FUERINT DIUERSA. COADUNATIS IGITUR EXISTENTIBUS UNA FIT UOCIS FORTITUDO ET SIMUL IMPELLIT AEREM. QUARE MULTIPLICITER PREIT, ETENIM EX OMNIBUS UOX UNIUSCUIUSQUE MULTIPLEX
PROPTER QUID LONGIUS .
Quare Querit quare vnus et idem numero eadem similiter voce cantans et
vociferans remotius auditur quando cum aliis vna una voce cantat et clamat quam si solus tantum cantaret aut vociferaret
? Non tamen adeo distantur distanter , sicut vnus post alium ordinatus distantia vociferaret vociferat
vt in vt in proicientibus lapidem successiue.

Deinde.
AUT. AUT QUIA. Soluit dicens primo causam esse causam esse primo
quia coniunctim aliquid agere, puta est
reprimere coangustante coangustare coangustando
an aut
impellere compellere contendendo, vel aliquid singulariter simile tale, non tamen tantum potest per se vnumquodque vnum per se ,
sicut quando plura quantum quando duo simul coniunguntur numerum constituentia, dummodo dum tamen
ordinentur ordinetur in vnum vt velut nauis tractus
ostendit.

Deinde.
SED SICUT. Declarat secundo dicens quod istud illud apparet ex tali simili quoniam sicut linea duorum pedum non solum duplum, sicut est potest figurare firmare
intellecta moueri, sed intellectum ymmo etiam
quadruplum et octuplum, secundum quod diuersimode mensurando applicatur infundo applicantur applicatur mensurando , ita vt super semper
plurem numerum habeat plurem numeri habeat pluralem numerum habeat plures vnam habeant potentiam, similiter et ad inuicem etiam
in quibuscunque quibusdam aliis. Cum autem plura fuerint numero amplius possunt, vel vel quam cum diuisa fuerint quocunque alio distinguente dummodo vnum proportionaliter compossit proportionaliter possit
alteri alteri coadunari .

Deinde.
COADUNATIS.
Concludit tertio quod quando quod
aliqua plura numero vel specie aut qualitercunque diuisa coniungantur coniunguntur ad inuicem virtute, vtpote in voce vna ex omnibus contingit contingit simul
vocum vocis fortitudo simul impellens aerem aera . Et ideo valde amplius amplius valde amplius potest preire et et in longinquius audiri quam vox vnius quod ostenditur. Nam ex voce uniuscuiusque vox quedam vna constituitur multiplicium habens potentiam, ceu seu tractus optime una et diuisim denotat nauis ostendit nauis . Et hoc quidem problema partim pertinet
.xie.
vt visum vt visum est particule Ps.-Arist. Prob. XI partimque isti.

div.head: Tertium problema
div.p:
PROPTER QUID PER YPATEM CANTANTES MAXIME RUMPIMUS NICHILOMINUS QUAM NITEM ET SUPERIORA, CUM DISTANTIA PLURI? AUT QUIA DIFFICILLIME HANC CANTANT, ET IPSA EST PRINCIPIUM? ID AUTEM DIFFICILE PROPTER ELEUATIONEM ET DEPRESSIONEM UOCIS. IN HIIS AUTEM LABOR, LABORANS AUTEM MAGIS CORRUMPITUR
PROPTER QUID PARYPATEM .
Quare Querit quare
cum cantamus cantantes secundum notam quam illa corda representat que vocatur ypotes potissime interrumpimus cantum, non potentes ipsum continuare sicut accepimus accipimus incepimus pre sui difficultate. Et in nullo minus videtur ymmo in omnibus etiam frangimus magnum cantum propter per ipsam quam per nitem vitem
siue seu netem. Et vniversaliter magis frangitur cantus et difficilius seruatur quando vtitur vtuntur notis per cordas superiores denotatis denotatur , et precipue quando distant inter se maxime. Hoc autem fit fit in fit instans sit instrumentis cantando aut per notas illas que sunt in instrumentis
proportionatas. proportionatis.

Notandum Notandum quod ad intellectum eius quod hic hic dicitur et multorum in hac particula dicendorum quod antiquitus a pictagora pitagoricis inuentum fuit instrumentum dictum monocordum, eo quod vnam solam cordam haberet taliter formatum talem formatum formatum taliter in quo proportiones musice .5e. cum tonis simplices prius cognosci iubebat videbantur secundum diuersitatem loci loci et instrumenti tacti representante. representantem. Deinceps inuenta sunt instrumenta inuenta fuerunt instrumenta cum pluribus cordis: vt duabus
ceu seu sicut rubeba que similiter organum introductum introductorium existit. Denique Deindeque Demumque Deinde quia paulatim sunt cetere adinuente inuente . Vnde 1° musice ait boecius nichomacum dicere musicam in principio fuisse simplicem in tantum quod tota constabat ex quatuor cordis. Quod durauit vsque ad orphei tempus puta, quod ex
prima prima quidem et quarta corda constitueret constituerent constabat
consonantiam duplam consonantia dupla dyapason dictam dicta . Medie quidem vero
harum ad se inuicem harum ad inuicem tonum constituebant, et ad extremas extremas partes comparate dyapente et dyatesseron, vt apparebit .13., ita vt in hiis quatuor cordis nichil dissonum existeret ad imitationem mutationem immutationem mundane musice antedicte que ex quatuor constat
vt tactum elementis vt tactum est elementis elementis vt tactum est . Quarum quatuor cordarum dicitur
mercurium inuentorem mercurius inuentor fuisse. Vnde adhuc aliqua aliquod alia instrumentorum videmus tantum vidimus quatuor cordas habere vt citaram et zigam. quintam vero cordam chorebus achis filius ac hiffilius lidorum rex adiunxit, hiagris quidem phirs sextam
apposuit apponit . Septimam Aliam vero terpanterius lesbius inuenit planetarum
septem
similitudinem similitudine . Inter quas grauissima erat, ypate dicta quasi maior et honorabilior honor vnde et iouem ypaton vocant id est et consulem eodem nomine nuncupantes propter dignitatis excellentiam. Septem vero fuisse cordas antiquitus testatur testabatur
.25.
et 32. et 33 et 34°
Et
attributa fuit is hec saturno propter tarditatem motus et grauitatem soni. Parypate vero 2a quasi iuxta ypatem collocata. Lychanos 3a. ideo quia lychanos digitus dicitur dicitur digitus quem latini indicem vocant; greci vero a lingendo ligando lychanos. Et quia in cantando cantando ad , hanc cordam tertiam ab ypate, digitus pertingit, quare ab ipso illo lychanos appellatur. Quarta vero dicitur mese
quasi
media quia quia media inter primam et septimam vere media est quarta. Quinta paramese quasi iuxta mediam collocata. Septima quidem dicitur nete quasi neate id est inferior. Inter quam et paramese est sexta dicta paranete quasi iuxta netem sita. Paranese Paramese autem quia 3a
est a nete eodem vocabulo trite id est tertia dicitur. Boeth. De inst. mus. I.20 (Friedlein pp. 205–6, ll. 28–9)
Fiat igitur ergo
talis cordarum talis parygrafia secundum thimotheum
precipuum in hac arte virum:
vt apparet apparet in
2° methaphysice Arist. Met. II.1, 993b, ll. 15–17 , incipiendo a superiori cordarum vocem grauissimam reddenti
ad inferius
descendendo vt usque ad ultimam acutissimam representantem:
Hypate prima.
Parypate secunda.
Lychanos tertia.
Mese quarta.
Paramese Paramese vel trite
quinta.
Paranete sexta.
Nete septima.

Et
iste quidem septem videntur esse ceteris essentialiores, ita vt aristoteles supra ipsas ipsas solas
non tangat non tangit tangat non
vt apparebit ullam nulli tamen , fueruntque fueritque fuerunt fuerunt qui consequenter 8 .9. et .10. .10. et .10. dixerunt iuxta illud psalmiste in psalterio decacordo decacordo psallam tibi . Psalm 143:9 (Psalm 144:9 in English translations) Et deinceps deinde
in tantum iterum
creuit numerus excreuit numerus exercuit numerus vt boecius 18 cum cum reiteratione ipsarum enumeret sub dyatonico melo et totidem sub cromatico ac 18 sub enarmonico cum variatione
quadam quedam communi sine zeugnum et diateuzeugnum. Non enim plura tribus sunt sunt tribus genera melorum quibus omnis contexitur cantilena. Cuius hec est descriptio Cuius est huius descriptio Quibus hec est descriptio
dyatonici
proslabanomenos
ypate ypaton
parypate ypaton
lychanos ypato dyatonici
ypate meson
parypate meson
lychanos meson dyatonici
mese
trite sinezeugium sinezeugnum dyatonici
paranete sinezeugium paranete sinezeumen diatonici
nete sunezeugium
paramese
trite diezeugium
paranete diezeugium dyatonici
nete diezeugium
trite yperboleon dyatonici trite yperboleon
paranete yperboleon dyatonici
nete yperboleon.
"Of the 'moveable' notes whose positions varied in different genera, Lychanos was treated as especially diagnostic of genus, and as a note-name it is sometimes augmented or replaced by enharmonios, chrōmatikē, or diatonos, depending on its actual station. The same happens more rarely with Paranētē" (M. L. West, Ancient Greek Music [Oxford: Clarendon Press, 1992], 222). Similis autem per omnia figuratio extat est figuratio in cromatico melo ac et
consimilis similis in enarmonico, excepto quod vt quod in prima subscribitur scribitur
dyatonici dyatonicum dyatonicis dyatonicus
ita ita vt in secunda cromaticon et in tertia enarmonicum, ita vt omnes coniuncte liiii. sunt sint corde. Moderni autem in aliquibus ultra lxiiii. apposuere vt medius canon canon dictus ostendit.

Trite dyazeugium
paranete dyezeugium dyatonici
zete dyezeugium

Nete yperboleon

Deinde.
AUT. AUT QUIA. Soluit dicens causam esse quia cum
difficultate ampliori
cantus fit secundum ypatem. Ipsa enim
est principium
incipiendo
superius, vt prescriptum prescriptum est ad quam. Si perueniri debet vocem oportet eleuare et ab ipsa versus netem deuenire venire , cum cantus perficiatur sonorus sonorum ex contrariis eleuando et deprimendo vocibus.

Deinde.
ID AUTEM.
Contingit Concludit Dicitur propter hoc quod quia contraria sunt subitam subicita inducentia alterationem. In hoc vero intercidit interdicit labor et difficultas, ubi autem huius hoc huiusmodi magis accidit corrumpi sicut etiam in aliis apparet potentiis. Et ideo agonizantes cantant leges et non choros 15°. Per alias vero cordas et proprie medias per oppositum cum difficultate cantatur minime
.

Circa predicta dubitatur Dubitatur circa dicta quoniam videmus plura plurima instrumenta habentia multo plures cordas quam que pretacte. Rota enim habet xliiii. vt .22.as in vno latere et in reliquo totidem
medius vero canon. lxiiii. et de aliis reliquis
similiter consimiliter . Dicendum quod ille plures reducuntur ad minores prius institutas. Quatuor 4 enim superadditarum sumuntur pro vna priorum priorum et , ita vt xxviii. 24
cadant
in .vii. notiores, et
.xliiii.
redeant redeunt in .xi. 12 et .lxiiii. in .xvi. Et similiter de aliis taliter variatis. Sicut
namque enim
quatuor positi sunt gradus medicinarum prius in tegni, Avic. Can. med. I, fen 2, 2.15
deinde quoque deindeque deinde quinto simplicium
vnusquisque
diuisus est est quilibet in tres mansiones, vt agnoscatur quantum possibile possibile est particularius complexio medicine medie . Ita posteriores musici non solum cordis fuere contenti quibus essentialiores et integraliores irregulariores denotarentur proportiones. Verum vt sonum solum amplius melodiosum construerent constituerent inter priores principaliores alias adiunxere adiuxerunt , ne inter eas magna permanerent interstitia in tristitia .

div.head: Quartum problema
div.p:
PROPTER QUID SECUNDUM HANC DIFFICULTER YPATEN, FACILE ETIAM DIUISIO ALTERIUS? AUT QUIA CUM REMISSIONE YPATE ET SIMUL POST DIMISSIONEM LEUE SURSUM PROICERE? PROPTER HOC AUTEM UIDETUR ET QUE DICUNTUR AD VNAM AD HANC QUAM CIRCA NITEM. OPORTET ENIM CUM DIMISSIONE ET REMISSIONE UALDE PROPRIA CONSUETUDINI AD UOLUNTATEM. HUIUS AUTEM UTIQUE CONSONANTIA QUEDAM CAUSA
PROPTER QUID SECUNDUM HANC .
Quare Querit quare secundum istam illam hanc cordam puta ypatem difficulter ? Et ideo dictum est
antea ante
secundum secundum eam interruptionem cantus peruenire prouenire
et licet cum difficultate cantetur. Tamen diuisio siue distinctio istius corde a quacunque alia est facilis et manifesta et proprie ab inferioribus, vt nete ac ei ea eis propinquis.

Deinde.
AUT. Soluit et prius ad id quod subdictum subditum
est secundo dicens dicit
illud id ideo esse quia faciendo remissionem et quasi quandam interpollationem cum cantus fiat cum ypate simulque simul que fere statim post durationem vel et
diuisionem dimissionem intonationis grauem, leue fit vocem sursum emittere, cum iam aliqualiter cantans quieuerit conuenerit emittendo spiritum et attrahendo emittendo sufficienter in vocis organa. Et ideo percipi videtur discretio in cantu facto facta per ypatem cum alia sibi opposita.

Deinde.
PROPTER HOC
. Assignat causam prioris premissi dicti dicens id illud
fore esse quia melodie que referuntur ad unam cordam, puta ad illam que est circa netem vt aut paranetem ac etiam paramese
facilime cantantur cantatur , eo quod non interuenit multa diuersitas vocum secundum acutum et grauem graue , sed tamen licet per ypatem parypatem cantetur difficulter propter grandem notarum distantiam differentiam . Cum
tamen fit sit vt tactum est
quadam dimissione et remissione reuersione quasi pausando ita ea reddatur ea redditur propria valde consuetudini per voluntatem acquisite, quis enim sic eligit, tunc vtique consuetudine inducta in cantando per ypatem. Secundum talem dimissionem et remissionem
licet de se cantetur difficilime illo autem modo illa autem minime, quoniam consuetudo difficilima etiam alleuiat cuncta iuxta illud
ypocratis afforisticis assueti assuetos ferre labores et reliqua. Hipp. Aph. II.49
Dicit autem voluntatem quia
consuetudo proprie proprie consuetudo in habentibus rationem acquiritur
apparens vt apparet
ethycorum secundo secundo ethicorum . Arist. Eth. Nic. II, 1103a l. 17

Deinde.
HUIUS HUIUSMODI AUTEM. Subdit tertio quod
etiam illud consonantia est aliqua alia causa eius huius , quod per ypatem parypatem cantus sepe non reputatur difficilius nam consonantia fessa restaurantur restauratur
vt visum et et vt visum est vt visum est et
vigorantur vigoratur debilitata. Εt ideo quesitum quare coram infirmis secundum alexander fistule ac tympana. Ps.-Alex. Aph. Prob. I.78 (Vat. reg.lat. 747, f. 75v)
Sic igitur licet de se difficulter cantetur ypate per accidens, tamen non in tantum, puta vel
ratione consuetudinis interuenientis aut delectabilis delectationis ipsius armonie, cum fuerit amicius ac amicius animi eius cum eius eius
adiecta adiuncta opposita, et quod quia distinctio maxime apparet in eo qui secundum ipsam cantu causatur .

div.head: Quintum problema
div.p:
PROPTER QUID DELECTABILITER AUDIUNT CANTANTES QUOSCUMQUE, UTIQUE PRESCIENTES ADIPISCUNTUR CANTUS, QUAM QUOS NESCIUNT? UTRUM QUIA MAGIS MANIFESTUS ADIPISCENS SICUT INTENTIONEM QUANDO COGNOSCUNT QUOD CANITUR? HOC AUTEM DELECTABILE CONSIDERARE, QUIA DELECTABILE DISCERE. HUIUS AUTEM CAUSA HOC QUIDEM ACCIPERE SCIENTIAM. HOC UERO UTI ET RECOGNOSCERE IPSAM. ADHUC AUTEM ET CONSUETUM DELECTABILE MAGIS INCONSUETO
PROPTER QUID DELECTABILITER .
Quare Querit quare cum delectatione maiori audiunt audiuntur homines cantatores ac etiam sonatores cantantes omnes illos cantus quorum preaudientes plaudientes
habuere habuerant habuerunt prius aliquam cognitionem? Siue sit sint
secundum verba, vt quod aliquid aliqui de ystoria gesti gesta iam audiuerint audierunt , vel demum de modo cantandi, eo quod audiuerint audierunt alias, illum et
consuetudinem aliquam inde inde aliquam acceperunt quam illos cantus quorum audientes
nullam habuerunt habuerint precognitionem omnino.

Deinde.
UTRUM. Soluit et prius probabilius magis magis probabiliter dicens illud id ideo esse quoniam quando homo aliquam prescientiam habuerit circa cantum quem audiuit quam audit , adipiscitur et attingit
ei quod est sibi magis manifestum. Et hoc declarat quemadmodum quando aliquis habuerit intentionem gesti quod cantatur et hystoriam eius quodammodo sciuit sciuerit presciuit , tunc hoc huic hunc intendere est delectabile precognoscentibus, eo quod iocundum est discere aliquid cuius non perfecte habetur cognitio, quod fit sit iterum audiendo vel considerare, vt continetur continetur in
.xl., ubi id hoc repetitur. Que duo interueniunt cum quis habet cognitionem gesti aliquam, nam ipse discit dixit in eo quod accipit scientiam cantus illius, eo quod gestum illud licet aliqualiter esset est scitum ab eo. Non tamen per modum melodie per motionem die promotionem die vtitur autem et considerat in
eo quod audit gestum cuius habuit habet cognitionem. Et ideo videmus homines vt plurimum cum volunt amplius quando volunt in
cantu cantum delectari facere sibi ystoriam gesti enarrare, tunc enim dupliciter delectantur delectatur
et melodia et ystoria et siquidem
cum habuerint hoc habuerint cum hoc habuerit
. Triplex enim tunc dilectatio concurrit consuetudinem audiendi predictum cantum cantum predictum aliquando in amplius delectantur delectatur
triplex enim tunc delectatio concurrit .

Deinde. Unde secundo confirmat causam prefatam, ADHUC AUTEM,
dicens dicit quod amplius ad hoc facit si quod sicut
auditur fuerit consuetum, auditur fuerit audiui
quia
consuetum magis delectat quam oppositum, cum sit facta factum natura quedam quadam et nobis
conuenientia conuenientiam . Quod autem
et et quomodo consueta delectent delectant , ostensum est est in sexto 18e., Ps.-Arist. Prob. 18.6, 917a ll. 6–17 et per oppositum quid agant opposita, et ideo audientes qui vnius videntur
lingue sunt lingue cantum alterius minime nisi consueti delectantur, cum neque ystoriam neque modum
cantandi precognouerint cantandi precognouerit precantandi cognouerit precanendi cognouerint . In opposito autem secus autem cetus , ceu seu sicut michi contingit per omne parisius cum ad gallos me transtuli. Vt autem id repetitum .xl.
exponatur exponitur omne, aristoteles talem addit causam, dicens ideo esse quoniam ille qui cantantem compatitur ipsi et ab ipso afficitur efficitur , propter voces quas exprimit que audienti auditui videntur denotare gaudium, et ideo consonat sibi id quod illud quod quod ille cantat. Et quadam naturali inclinatione ad delectationem mouetur mouetur ad delectationem in seipso ceu se seu ille mouetur. Quando enim natura vnius percipit naturam alterius congaudere aut tristari vel se purgare, natura etiam illius ad hoc mouetur mouetur ad hoc mouetur ad se hoc agendum, vt declaratum est
septima. Quare subdit in eius verificationem sermonis verificatione sermonis quod omnis cantans consonat sibi et alium reddit consonum et affectum affectantem , dummodo illum cantum non exprimat propter necessitatem, vt sperans superans
ita inde
victum vitum lucrari ceu vt ystriones aut metu pene vel tristitia, et huius huiusmodi propter que talia cantantes
non magne magis
consonant consonans aliis et maxime extraneis ab illo cantu et sibimet ipsis
minime.

div.head: Sextum problema
div.p:
PROPTER QUID PAR YPATE SECUNDUM RATIONEM IN CANTIBUS TRAGICUM. AUT PROPTER INEQUALITATEM? PASSIUUM ENIM INEQUALE, ET IN MAGNITUDINE FORTUNE AUT TRISTITIE. EQUALE AUTEM MINUS PLORABILE UEL ULULABILE PROPTER QUID PARYPATE
.
Quare Querit quare rationabile existit est quod genus cantandi
tragicum per ypatem cantetur? Nosce quod
circa genus armonicum armoniarum vel armonicum quodcumque duplicem maneriem cantandi constare, quedam enim est comedia comedia et altera tragedia. Est autem comedia canticum agreste que
res priuatarum et humilium habilium personarum
comprehendit comprehendens , et dicitur a cosmos quod est villa vel laus
secundum aliquos. Grece tamen mundus et odi cantus quasi mundanus et vulgaris cantus, de rebus enim
vulgaribus tractat et affinibus cotidiane locutionis locutioni . Vel dicitur a commessatione a commessatione quia a commiseratione a commensuratione accessatione post cibum, enim
homines solebant ad eam audiendam conuenire. Tragedia vero est modus carminis carminum quo poete in luctibus regum vtebantur. Dicta Dictus a tragos quod est dicitur yrcus et odi cantus quod est cantus
quasi inde hyrcinus cantus. Et quia materia erat tristis tristis et
feda seda , huiusmodi huius animal vt yrcum pro munere numero
poematis
accipiebant additur. Et Etiam
maneries a quibus 3° maneries a quibusdam 3a satira dicta que carmine construitur constituitur
reprehensorio reprehensoris
ceu seu sicut modus oratii fuit fuit oratii maxime.

Deinde.
AUT. Soluit dicens causam esse sumptam ab inequalitate, vtrobique enim videlicet inest quedam inequalitas, vt in cantu tragico et per ypatem parypaten facto, propter eius eam esse
supremum supremam . Nam in vnoquoque istorum est quedam passio et difficultas, quod autem tale tale est , siue seu Inequale seu sit in magnitudine
fortune fortitudine ceu cantus magne letitie alicuius magnatis magnatis et probitatis, siue in magnitudine
tristitie, sicut mortis alicuius excellentis vel
huiusmodi huius , est inequale, non eundem seruans tenorem. Quod autem est inequale et dissonum rationabile rationale est, vt cantu exprimatur huiusmodi huius , vt pondus meloticum configeretur rei de qua existit. Tunc cantus consurgit eurithimus sicut de huius huiusmodi pulsu scribitur de differentiis pulsuum a galeno. Gal. De diff. puls. I.8 (I.12 in Latin trans. by Burgundio of Pisa)
Cf. Pietro d'Abano Conciliator diff. 83
Ceu Seu in bellis tubarum clangor bellantes concitat in furorem, in oppositis autem vt in choreis oppositum expetitur experitur , ac similiter in mortuorum lamentatione. Et id illud hoc est quod subditur subdit a contrariis probando pretactum, inquiens quod illud quod est equale in cantu et vnum conseruans tenorem non est plorabile proportionabile aut ululabile lamentabile , cum non sit quid passiuum, propter quod non est conueniens ipsum parypatem per ypatem cuius est inequalitatem tenere sed per alias cordarum cordas
mitiores anteriores exponere.

Nosce quod pondus est illud in quo quod proportiones
secundum auicenna
cadunt musice musice cadunt . Avic. Can. med. Book I, fen 2, 3 (p. 141 of 1608 ed.) Hoc autem pondus rebus expedit expedit conformari rebus circa quas extat configurari
, cum eo exprimantur passiones que sunt in anima.
Voces enim sunt note passionum que sunt in ea anima
illeque rerum primo peryarmenias. Arist. Peri herm. I.1, 16a ll. 5–6
Vnde si res fuerit alta altera in signis contingit conuenit tragedia ipsam exprimere. Si autem econtra comedia vt modus coaptetur rei ceu seu proprietas subiecto.

div.head: Septimum problema
div.p:
PROPTER QUID ANTIQUI SEPTEM CORDARUM FACIENTES ARMONIAM YPATEM, SED NON NITEM RELIQUERUNT? UTRUM HOC MENDACIUM, UTRAMQUE ENIM RELIQUERUNT, TERTIAM UERO ELEUAUERUNT? AUT NON, SED QUIA GRAUIOR FORTIFICAT ACUTIORIS SONUM, QUARE MAGIS YPATE REDDIT ANTIFONUM QUAM NITE? QUIA ACUTUM POTENTIA MAGIS, GRAUE AUTEM FACILIUS CANTATUR PROPTER QUID ANTIQUI
.
Quare Querit quare est quod antiquitus constituentes constitutiones armoniam musicalem ex septem cordis diuiserunt dimiserunt ypatem non
auferentes ipsam eam ab armonia, non autem relinquerunt nete netem ,
verum velut
inde abstulerunt inabstulerunt ?

Deinde.
UTRUM. Soluit et prius primo
problema probatur probabitur probabiliter dicens id illud
non esse non esse verum quod premissum est
, quoniam non seruauerunt solum solum seruauerunt ypatem, ymmo vtramque vtraque puta ypatem et netem. Sed quam abstulerunt fuit tertia, vt paramese vel lychanos, vtraque enim est tertia
eius huius quod est septem esse esse 7 cordas. Vnde 32° dicetur quod tripandius extrahens tertiam cordam a septicordo netem apposuit apponunt . Sic ergo igitur per interemptionem interpretationem soluit.

Deinde.
AUT NON. Soluit magis ad orationem rationem
secundo
dicens dicit
nichil hoc esse quod dicitur vt quod abstulissent netem et dimisissent stare ypatem. Sed hoc dictum fortassis ex hoc pullulauit, quia sonus cordis corde grauis vigorat fortificat figurat sonum acutioris. Suo enim multo tempore et duratione graue substentat acutum ne cito pereat cum breui tempore feriat. Propter quod ypate longo tempore aere aerem percutiente quam quem nete reddat, ob eius acuitatem, que potentia ponitur vel fortitudine indiget in cantando, difficile namque acutum cantare sed graue facilius, sicut pluries dicetur. Sic itaque quia grauis corda sonum fortificat acute et ad se conuertit. et quia difficile difficilime est
acutum cantare, quis credidit ex hoc cum nete netem sonum non perciperet percipet percipiet proprium quod esset sublata? Et fortassis aliquis leget illud istud illud vt tactum multe
QUIA ACUTUM.
quod aliam solutionem subiungat.

Nosce quod armonia que est vna trium partium vt tactum est musice vt tactum musice musice vt tactum est
, proprie pertinet ad comedos et tragedos uel choros, et omnino ad eos qui precipue voce cantant. Ex ea namque causatur causatur talis armonia que est vocis vocum modulatio et concordia plurium sonorum vel coaptatio. Simphonia est vocis vocum modulatio temperata ex graui et acuto accordantibus acuto a cordantibus sonis, cuius quidem contraria contraria est dyaphonia. Euphonia est suauitas vocis vocum , hec autem melos a melle et suauitate dicta. Dyastema est vocis vocum spatium ex duobus uel pluribus sonis coaptatum coadaptatum . Dyesis est spatia spatium
quedam et quoddam
deducens deductiones modulandi et vergendi de vno in alterum sonum. Isidore of Seville, Etym., III.20.1–6
Boecius autem
dyesim dicit dicit Dyesim
vnius minus fore semitonii. Boeth. De inst. mus. II.28 (Friedlein p. 260, ll. 21–24)
Tonus est autem
acuta vocis vocis acuta acuta arta vocis enunciatio. Αrsis quidem vocis eleuatio, thesis depressio. Isidore of Seville, Etym., III.20.7, 9 Sic igitur ex symphonia potest haberi quod antiphonum vel antiphona sit quedam modulatio vel et intonatio contra simphoniam, vt sonus qui post eam refrangitur auditum demultiens.

div.head: Octauum problema
div.p:
PROPTER QUID GRAUIS ACUTE FORTIFICAT SONUM? AUT QUIA MAIUS HOC GRAUE? OBTUSO ENIM ASSIMULATUR, HOC UERO ACUTO ANGULO PROPTER QUID GRAUIS
.
Quia Quare dixerat grauem cordam sonum fortificare acute,
causam siquidem querit querit causam huius dicens quare quia grauis corde sonus vigorat vigilat eum qui acute?

Deinde.
AUT. Soluit dicens causam esse quoniam illud quod est graue maius est et fortius. Quod ostenditur quoniam angulo simulatur si multiplicatur
obtuso acuto trianguli, quod quidem maior est et fortior etiam
vigore acuto acuto vt res ostendunt nature et artis, acutum vero angulo proportionatur acuto
,
ceu seu minori et debiliori. Quod autem maius maius est et fortius vigorat quod minus et debilius,
huius huiusmodi quidem graue acuti respectu, quare ipsum vigorat, vt .xii. etiam apparebit
.

div.head: Nonum problem
div.p:
PROPTER QUID DELECTABILITER UNITATEM CANTUS AUDIMUS SI QUIS AD FISTULAM AUT LYRAM CANTAT ET AD CORDAS, ET EUNDEM CANTUM CANTANT UTROBIQUE? SI ENIM ADHUC MAGIS IDEM, POTIUS OPORTEBAT AD MULTOS FISTULATORES ET ADHUC DELECTABILITER ESSE. AUT QUIA ADIPISCENS MANIFESTUS INTENTIONEM MAGIS QUANDO AD FISTULAM AUT LYRAM? QUOD UERO AD MULTOS FISTULATORES AUT LYRAS MULTAS NON EST DELECTABILE PROPTER ID QUOD DESTRUIT MELODIAM PROPTER QUID DELECTABILITER
.
Quare Querit quare
cum delectatione delectabiliter audimus unitum seu in vnum coniectum coniunctum , vt si quis cantat in fistula vel lyra et vniuersaliter in cordis ceu seu
in
psalterio canone et huius huiusmodi instrumentis ex cordis multis compositis, dummodo vtrobique cantet causet eundem cantum? Quoniam si vnus cantus seu dantia fieret in
in vno instrumento et alius alius in voce cantantis causantis canentis , in etiam illo non consurgeret consurget propter dissonantiam delectatio.

Deinde.
SI ADHUC. Quasi arguit in contrarium dicens quod si unius huius huiusmodi talis delectatio contingat propter vnitatem cantus et ydemptitatem, tunc oportebit magis delectari cum quis cantabit cum multis fistulantibus uel lyrantibus, cum magis videantur videatur super vnum opus unitari imitari , vt plures trahentes nauem imitantur vnitantur , vt melius trahant.

Deinde.
AUT. Soluit dicens causam esse quia quoniam
cum aliquis cantat cantet
singulariter signanter singulariter cantat intentionem et maneriem cantus magis vnitatur vox cum sono instrumenti quam quando cum cantaret in diuersis instrumentis, etiam et eodem cantu vtrobique existente. Et hoc quia in cantu quedam quid reseruantur proportiones vt dicetur commensurate. Quibus obseruatis iocunda consurgit consistit armonia, que quidem corrumpitur et indelectabilis redditur cum cantans ad multa cantauerit instrumenta.

Quod autem inductum inductum est
in ad contrarium prius non valet quia licet multi possint idem cantare, non tamen eodem modo. Non solum enim requiritur Et non requitur solum ydemptitas ex parte illius quod cantatur et cuiuslibet cantantis ad se ipsum ymo uniuscuiusque uniuscuiusque et ad alium et ad omnes, ita quod ex omnibus resultent proportiones debite in cantu. Quod autem subditur subdit subicitur subiecti subieci de nauis tractu tractu nauis tractu nauis uel ligni non
huic hoc
similatur assimilatur dicto, quoniam plurimi possunt simul idem idem simul vt nauem eodem modo et tempore trahere vt audientes vocem rectoris nauis. Non Vt autem talis vnitas potest in cantu plurium obseruari reseruari armonico, cum eum enim
ex
pluribus et contrariis oporteat constituere construere in unum unam . Tandem redditur redditis reductis quod fit sit impossibile pluribus entibus vocibus et in
instrumentis.

div.head: Decimum problema
div.p:
PROPTER QUID SI DELECTABILIS HOMINIS UOX QUE SINE SERMONE CANTANTIS NON DELECTABILE EST UT UERNANTIUM, SED FISTULA AUT LYRA? AUT NON ILLIC, SI NON IMMUTATUR, SIMILITER DELECTABILE? AT UERO SED PROPTER OPUS IPSUM. UOX ENIM DELECTABILIS QUE EST HOMINIS, PERCUSSIUA AUTEM MAGIS INSTRUMENTA ORIS. PROPTER QUOD DELECTABILIUS AUDIRE QUAM UERNARE PROPTER QUID NON DELECTABILIS
.
Quare Querit quare si vox humana est delectabilis auditu auditui , unde
museus musicus dicitur
politicorum 8° .8vo. politicorum
delectabilissimum delectabili fine quod delectabilissimum est hominibus cantare, Arist. Pol. VIII, 1339b, l. 22
cum quis aliquis cantat etiam
non proferendo sermonem omnino aut insignificatium insignium , cur
non est delectabilis delectabilis est
vox alicuius uernantium Videtur tamen , cum sit hominis vox, et eti etiam lyre et fistule sonus est delectabilis? Qui Que minorem communicationem videtur cum homine cum homine videtur habere quam vox ipsa humana. In hiis itaque uerbis aristoteles succincte tetigit motiuum quesiti et confirmationem eius.

Notandum quod vernare vocis vocem est expressionem facere in qua non manifestatur manifestetur aliqua sensibilis subtilitas diuersitas extensione et depressione vocis, ita quod eius remaneat equalitas, ad modum quo ver equale ponitur ponitur equale a medicis. Est enim quasi illud quod dicitur
bordonizare quod
per se minime minimam
videtur
delectationem inducere.

Deinde.
AUT. Soluit et prius primo respondet ad confirmationem, dicens quod illic scilicet in fistula fistulis et lyra non est delectari, quoniam similiter in eis ita se habet etiam se habet eis vt in
vernante, quia quoniam si non fiat immutatio soni secundum ascensionem et depressionem, vt inde consurgant desurgant debite proportiones armonice, non contingit delectari ex huius huiusmodi instrumenti sono. Sic Sicut igitur uernare non est delectabile, eo quod proportiones non cadunt
in ipso
melite multipliciter auditum demulcentes demulceantes .

Deinde.
AUT AT UERO. Respondet motiuo ipsius causam dando dando causam quare vox humana cantantis sit delectabilis. Hoc enim est propter operationem ex qua consequitur. In ipsa namque magis percutiuntur instrumenta oris ordinata ad formationem cantus delectabilis quam in ex uernare. Ex huius huiusmodi
namque autem
maiori maiore percussione instrumentorum oris que fit in cantu, nunc in vocem extollendo nunc tunc in deprimendo, modo vero medie conseruando resultat cantus modus armonicus suauis valde. Et ideo inquit delectabilius fore esse vocem hominis cantantis audire, cum hic huiusmodi huius contingat quam vocem vernantis, ubi minime. Vox etiam hominis delectabilis quia consueta et quoniam potest mutari componi et et potest contraponi facillime.

div.head: Vndecimum problema

p.mentioned:
PROPTER QUID SONANS ACUTIOR? AUT QUIA MINUS IMBECILLIOR FACTA EST PROPTER QUID SONANS
.
p.gloss: Quare Querit quare aliquis sonans sonitu uel voce acutior redditur et per consequens alius grauior?

div.p:
Deinde.
AUT. Soluit dicens causam esse quia hic
sonans est minus sonans quam illud quod grauiter sonat.
Quod autem sit minus ostenditur quia fit a virtute que quia facta est imbecillior. Grauiter autem sonans a virtute causatur fortiori fortiori causatur , propter quod dictum est
.xia.
quod pueri femine eunuchi eunuci et infirmi habent voces acutas, Ps.Arist. Prob. XI.16, 900b, ll. 15–17 oppositi autem vero graues propter per oppositum.

div.head: Duodecimum problema
div.p:
PROPTER QUID CORDARUM GRAUIOR SEMPER SONUM ACCIPIT? SI ENIM OPORTET DIMITTERE QUE EST CIRCA MEDIAM PARAMESEM CUM MEDIA ALTERA, FIT MEDIUM NIHILOMINUS. SI AUTEM MEDIA UTRAQUE, ALTA NON FUERIT. AUT QUIA GRAUE MAGNUM EST, QUARE FORTE? ET INEST IN MAGNO PARUUM, ET ASSUMPTIONE DUE NITE IN YPATE FIUNT PROPTER QUID CORDARUM
.
Quare Querit quare de cordis illa que grauioris extat est toni semper accipit sonum tonum
et representat pre aliis ipsum vt subiectum proprietatem, dum tamen equaliter fiat percussio et ad hoc adhuc , si oportet propter aliquam causam vt
defectum ipsius aut aliter aliquando dimittere paramese que est iuxta mediam, scilicet iuxta mese siue mediam
uere ipsa hec . Namque septem cordarum vt visum est media
cum alia quodammodo media quodammodo cum aliquo existente vt lychanos, ita quod ea sonum sonus
non nisi
constituatur constituat in armonia. Nihilominus ex
extremis puta ypate nete parypate etiam et et etiam etiam paranete, sicut ex illis tribus mediis
resultat quoddam medium constitutiuum armonie, in quo grauior cordarum sonum preaccipit aliis acutis. Communis quidem littera circa mediam partem partem habet
hoc
tamen licet possit tollerari series tamen iam exposita continens paramese planior et sauior sauior et planior planior et senior .
Sed Et si vtraque media vtreque medie
coniungantur coniungatur ad inuicem vtpote dicatur intermediarum, sicut sunt est lychanos mese paramese siue trite, non constituitur sonus eleuatus, ita vt inde resultet grauis, tanquam corde cordis grauioris reddentis sonum grauiorem, cum sonus harum earum
existat extat in medio inter graue grauem et acutum. Sic itaque videtur duo querere puta quia quare grauior cordarum sonum preaccipiat et cur cum
ex
extremis concursus fiat in medium reddens grauem sonum non autem ex mediis.

Deinde.
AUT. AUT QUIA.
Soluit dicens causam esse quia
id illud
quod
graue magnum et forte diuque perdurans permanens seu perdurans preaccipit vigorem sui oppositi, talis siquidem est grauior cordarum ad alias, etiam et in magno continetur et continuo et
et
occultatur parvuum, sicut in superiori siteriorum , taliter quod sonus duarum nitarum assumptus est in sono vno parypatem causato. Ex quo habetur quod grauior cordarum sonum preaccipit, et quod
ex ultimis extremis extremis ultimis medium potest resultare, sicut apparebit .23° 22° .

div.head: Tertiumdecimum problema

p.mentioned:
PROPTER QUID IN DYAPASON ACUTI QUIDEM ANTIFONUM FIT GRAUE, HUIUS AUTEM ACUTUM NON? AUT QUIA MAXIME QUIDEM IN AMBOBUS EST AMBORUM MELODIA? SI AUTEM NON, NON GRAUE, MAIUS ENIM EST PROPTER QUID IN DYAPASON
.
p.gloss: Quare Querit quare in proportione illa que dicitur dyapason vel proportio dupla uel totius tonus , illud quod habet rationem acuti plerumque pertransit transit in grauem graue , quod autem illud autem quod habet rationem grauis non permutatur in acutum?

div.p:
Videndum Videndum est nunc gratia eius huius quod dicitur dyapason quot et que sunt sint proportiones musicales musicales et quomodo sumantur, et quia dico quod originantur ex proportionibus arismetricis intuendum prius illas.
Sunt autem secundum boecium in primis arismetrice et musice numeri
quinque
sumpte sumptis penes numerum inequalem. Quarum tres sunt simplices puta multiplex et submultiplex multiplex submultiplex multiplex , superparticularis et
subsuperparticularis, superpartiens et subsuperpartiens. Due autem composite quarum prima componitur ex multiplici et superparticulari
et ex et
multiplici supermultiplici submultiplici et subsuperparticulari, secunda ex multiplici superparticulari et submultiplici submultiplici et
subsuperparticulari subsuperpartiente . Boeth. De inst. mus. I.4 (Friedlein p. 191, ll. 6–10) Boeth. De inst. arith. I.22 (Friedlein p. 46, ll. 6–17)

Multiplex autem est quando est
numerus maior minorem in se continet continens pluries, vt bis vel ter aut vel quater deinceps, vt nichil desit nichilque exsuperet. Huius Huiusmodi autem species sunt duplex triplex quadruplex et sic in infinitum. Duplex quidem cum vt vnus numerus alium bis continet que dicitur proportio dupla vt quatuor ad duo. Triplex cum vnus numerus continet alium totum numerum
tribus vicibus sicut trinarius se habet ad vnitatem ad vnitatem se habet .

Proportio autem secunda iuxta aliam inequalitatem, vt superparticularis cum eius opposita opponitur , est cum maior numerus
continet in se totum semel et et adhuc vnam eius insuper
partem, vt aut dimidia dimidiam
vel aut
tertia tertiam et ita deinceps. Cuius Huius quidem proportionis modi sunt sexquialtera,
sexquitertia uel epitrita sexquinta uel epitrica sexquitertia , sexquiquarta et huius huiusmodi . Sexquialtera seu emiola est cum quis aliquis numerus alium semel continet et insuper eius mediam partem partem eius mediam , vt ternarius se habet ad binarium ternarius ad binarium se habet . Sexquitertia
cum
semel et eius tertiam partem, vt quaternarius ad ternarium.

Superpartiens est
quando maior numerus continet minorem et insuper eius aliquas aliquas eius partes, vt duas
3as
tres et cetera. Cuius species sunt superbipartiens supertripartiens et cetera. Superbipartiens est cum numerus continet numerum semel et eius duas partes, vt quinarius ad ternarium se habet. Supertripartiens
Supertripartiens est quando semel continet totum et eius
tres partes tertiam partem , vt septem se habet ad quatuor. Superquadripartiens et cetera, vt etiam, sicut .ix. se habet
ad .5.

Compositarum Compositorum vero multiplex superparticularis est cum numerus continet maior maior continet minorem totum multotiens et insuper aliquam aliam partem eius, vt medietatem uel tertiam et huius. Huius Huiusmodi autem species sunt sunt species duplex sexquialtera,
duplex sexquitertia duplex sexquitertia et , duplex sexquiquarta, et cetera, et id ratione id rationem
duplicitatis duplicis ; ex parte vero triplicitatis triplicis
triplex sexquialtera,
triplex sexquitertia triplex sexquitertia duplex sexquitertia , et cetera triplex et cetera triplex sexquiquarta .
Est
duplex sexquialtera quando maior numerus numerus bis
continet
minorem totum et insuper eius partem mediam, vt
.5. quinarius se habet ad .2 binarium . Duplex sexquitertia quando est quando quando ipsum continet totum et ipsius eius tertiam partem, vt septem se habet ad .3. Duplex sexquiquarta et cetera
, vt .ix. se habet
ad quatuor. Triplex sexquialtera Triplex sexquitertia
est
quando alter alterum continet totum continet alterum totum ter
et vt adhuc eius tertiam partem, vt decem ad tria. Triplex sexquialtera Quadruplex sexquialtera
Triplex sexquiquarta
quando est quando quartam partem continet ultra totum, vt .13. ad quatuor.

Multiplex superpartiens est
cum maior numerus continet minorem plus quam semel uel multotiens et pluries plures , cum hoc ipsius partem partes . Cuius etiam infinite sunt sunt infinite species, vt duplex superbipartiens duplex superpartiens , duplex supertripartiens et cetera, duplex supertripartiens triplex superpartiens
, et cetera, et id ratione duplicitatis; ex parte quidem quid
triplicitatis erunt triplex superbipartiens, triplex supertripartiens triplex superpartiens , et cetera. Duplex superbipartiens est quando numerus maior continet continet bis minorem et insuper duas eius partes, vt octo se habet habent ad triam tria . Duplex supertripartiens et cetera est est quando , vt xi. se habet ad .3. Quadruplex superbipartiens
Triplex supertripartiens
est quando
et cetera, vt .15. se habet habent ad quatuor. Hee quidem qua sunt numerorum inequalitates inequales ex quibus quinque
resultant proportiones arismetrice cum suis oppositis antedictis.

Restat quidem breuiter videre secundo breuiter quidem videre secundo breuiter 2° videre : quot et que que et quot sunt ex hiis sint sunt
consonantie siue simphonie
musicales, et a quibus quibus proportionibus
sumantur summatur sumuntur
arismetricis arismetricum . Secundum quidem quid
macrobium et boecium ex omni numerorum varietate pauci numeri
reperiuntur qui conueniant sibi ad consonantiam musicalem constituendam. Sunt autem hii sex omnes omnis iuxta quos quinque consonantie constituuntur, et tonus ex quo constituunt constituitur dyatonum, scilicet epitricus, emiolus, duplaris, triplaris, quadruplarus quadruplum , epogdous epogdonium .

Epitricus vel sexquitertius est vt aliqualiter iam patuit cum maior numerus continet minorem totum et eius tertiam partem, vt quatuor
se habet
ad tria. Ex quo nascitur simphonia uel consonantia dyatesseron dicta dicta dyatesseron id est per quatuor, que in sexquitertia proportione consistit consistit proportione , vt cum una vox in grauitate vel acuitate se se habuerit ad aliam sicut quatuor ad tria hii .

Iuxta vero emiolam uel sexquialteram vt cum maior numerus
minorem continet continet minorem totum et medietatem ipsius ipsius medietatem , ceu seu vt
se habet
tria ad duo. Oritur consonantia dicta dyapente uel per quinque quandoque
in quinto enim in quinto loco terminatur in monocordo, sicut dyatesseron in quatuor quarto
ceu seu cum una vox se habuerit ad aliam in grauitate et leuitate et cetera.

Secundum siquidem quidem
duplarem numerum vel proportionem, vt quatuor se habet ad duo sumitur proportio dyapason siue per totum, terminat enim et uel continet totum monacordum et maxime primum, cadit enim super octo 4 incipiens a gama greco.

Scilicet
iuxta vero triplarem triplarem vero numerum seu proportionem, vt cum numerus se habet habeat ad numerum ceu sicut
tria ad vnum, componitur enim ex multiplici et superparticulari sicut se habet tria ad vnum
, nascitur simphonia composita vt ex
dyapente dyapente et dyapason vt quando vna
vox excedit alteram et cetera. Iuxta vero numerum quadruplum, cum vnus alium quater continet, vt quatuor se habet ad vnum oritur bis diapason.

Epogdous est numerus qui inter intra se minorem concludit continet et insuper octauam 8 , eius partem ceu seu sicut
nouem se habet ad octo. Ex hoc quo quidem numero sonus consurgit quem musici tonum vocant tonum vocarunt tonum vocauerunt , qui autem tono minus semitonum dicitur, quod non non est
extimandum existimandum tonum vere fere fore sicut neque semiuocalem in litteris. Non enim Nam tonus naturaliter in duo equalia
potest diuidi, cum constet ex numero nouenario, quod qui in duo diuidi minime potest equaliter potest equaliter potest . Vnde et Et ideo
semitonium vocarunt vocauerunt semitonum sonum tono minorem. Est autem semitonum duplex maius scilicet scilicet maius maius et minus. Maius Minus
quidem videm quid dicitur apothomi, apud vero boecium decisio, minus autem aut dyesis uel limes, quod tam paruo distare a tono deprehensum est quantum hii
duo numeri distant: vt
.243. et 256 2256 . Quorum quidem vnusquisque constat ex duabus vocibus puta prout
vt vt et mi, est et etiam ditonus, qui ex duobus consurgit perfectis tonis, et semidytonus semitonus , qui ex duobus non integris integer . Vt id autem autem hec per amplius appareat apparent parigraphia conscribatur scribatur
ista talis .

Sunt itaque consonantie quinque scilicet: dyatesseron, dyapente, dyapason, dyapente dyapason, et dyapente dyapason dyatesseron et bis dyapason. Que quidem hiis tonis et semitonis constituuntur, dyatesseron diatonici enim constat ex duobus tonis et semitono non integro, dyapente tribus tonis et minore semitono
, dyapason quinque tonis et semitonis duobus duobus semitonis minoribus, neque nullaque
peruenit prouenit prout ad .vi. quinque tonos perfecte. Ex quibus apparet quod dyatesseron et dyapente diapentesseron
consurgunt consurgit in dyapason diapasseron
. Dyapente dyapason Dyapente dyapason que Et in pentadyaseron ex .ix. tonis et ex et semitono minori constat, bis vero sed ipsa bis dyapason ex .12.
perficitur perfectis tonis. Et hec quidem
amplius sunt sunt exposita in
conciliatoris mei conciliatoris nostri conciliatoris
differentia .83a.
exposita
. Pietro d'Abano Concil. diff. 83

Nosce quoque
ex musice quinto ex quinto musice
quod ptholomeus sextam hiis addit
sextam hiis addidit addidit sextam consonantiam compositam ex dyatesseron et dyapason, que constat ex multiplici superpartiente superpartienti superparticulare
qua proportione quam proportionem in qua proportione
se habet habet
octo ad .3.. Continet enim octo bis tria, propter multiplicem proportionem ex qua visum visum est consurgere dyapason, et duas
eius partes partes eius eius partes eius quod est tertia 3. scilicet duo propter superpartientem a qua nascitur dyatesseron. Boeth. De inst. mus. V.8–9
Communiter tamen pictagorici musice
institutores instructores posuerunt omnes proportiones consonantias musicales consurgere ex multiplici et superparticulari, nullamque nullam vero ex superpartiente superpartienti , quod videtur aristoteles sentire xli.

Deinde.
AUT. Soluit dicens causam esse quoniam quia in ambobus scilicet in
graui et acuto est melodia vtrorumque, vnum enim alteri coniunctum consitum melodiam reddit, quia graue et acutum sunt dissimilia.
Et
thimoteus entimomus quidem extimauit existimauit musice primo melodiam uel consonantiam fieri ex dissimilibus, non autem ex similibus consimilibus . Si autem proueniat vtrorunque in vtrisque concordia non fit melodia, cum autem sic fuerit quod graue maius sit sit maius acuto et fortius, tunc quod est acutum assumit rationem grauis, ita quod acutum sentitur graue, vt nisi cum due nite concurrunt concordant in ypatem. Dicitur autem melodia a melle, quoniam est consonantia delectabilissima valde ex acuto et graui debite composita.

div.head: Quartumdecimum problema
div.p:
PROPTER QUID LATET DYAPASON ET UIDETUR UNIUS SONI ESSE, UT IN FINIKIO ET IN HOMINE? QUE ENIM IN ACUTIS EXISTUNT NON UNIUS SONI, SED PROPORTIONALITER AD INUICEM DYAPASON. AUT QUIA SICUT IPSE ESSE UIDETUR SONUS PROPTER ANALOGUM, EQUALITAS IN SONIS, EQUALE AUTEM UNIUS? HOC AUTEM IDEM IN FISTULIS DECIPIUNTUR PROPTER QUID LATET DYAPASON
.
Quare Querit quare dyapason cum sit proportio satis distans quoniam dupla latet in tantum iterum
quod quare videtur sonus ex ipsa resultatus resultans esse vnus et quasi vnum tonum simpliciter habere? Et hoc declarat sicut apparet et cetera
. Communiter quidem inuenitur littera in finitis, alia infantis
aliter finikio alia finikio
, sed forte debet dicere in fidibus dici in fidibus esse in fidibus seu cordis. Et in homine similiter
declarat declaratur ita quod per hoc tangat duplicem melodiam tactu uel pulsu factam et voce note . Soni siquidem existentes acuti quia non concurrunt adeo in vnum, non sunt unius minus soni vt graues aut sic sunt compositi ex grauibus sed in dyapason. Hoc accidit quoniam toni se habent proportionaliter ad inuicem ex graui et ex acuto, est enim optima consonantiarum
.35 tria quinto .

Deinde.
AUT. Soluit dicens causam esse quare quia sonus apparet vnicus esse propter anologiam et proportionem sonorum ad inuicem in dyapason, ex qua resultat equalitas grandis in sonis. Quod autem equalitatem habet habet equalitatem
vnius unus
soni existit existit soni , et non solum hoc
accidit in sono
voce facto
aut
pulsu, sed etiam
in sono
flatu facto, vel vt in fistulis. In illis enim decipiuntur etiam vt in vocis sono, propter debitam enim enim debitam tonorum consonantiam accidit plures tonos non discerni sed vnum apparere cum diuersitates illic non extent existant sensibiles, ceu seu videmus ex in saporibus composita ex compositis ex composita diuersis in quibus vnus consurgit delectabilis et nullius excessus,
vt vt qui conficitur decoctione ex
cucurbitis cucurbite , cepis, uel alleis aliis , cum tamen vnum sit saporis insipidi et alterum acuti.

div.head: Quintumdecimum problema
div.p:
PROPTER QUID LEGES QUIDEM NON IN CONUERSIONIBUS FACIEBANT, ALII UERO CANTUS CHORICI? AUT QUIA LEGES QUIDEM AGONIZANTIUM FUERUNT? QUIBUS UTIQUE MUTARI POTENTIBUS ET DISTENDI, CANTUS FIEBAT LONGUS ET MULTIFORMIS. QUEMADMODUM IGITUR ET UERBA, ET CANTUS MUTATIONEM SEQUEBANTUR, SEMPER ALTERA FACTA. MAGIS ENIM CANTU NECESSE IMITARI QUAM UERBIS. PROPTER QUOD ET DITIRAMBI, QUONIAM AUTEM IMITATIUI, FIEBANT. NON ADHUC HABENT CONUERSIUOS, PRIUS AUTEM HABEBANT. CAUSA AUTEM QUONIAM ANTIQUITUS LIBERI ROTABANT IPSI, MULTOS IGITUR AGONISTICE CANTARE DIFFICILE ERAT, QUARE IN ARMONIA CANTUM DELECTABILITER.
